meanings.def: in a good, right or acceptable way
examples: They played well in the tournament.
The team work well together.
The kids all behaved well.
The conference was very well organized.
Well done! (= expressing admiration for what somebody has done)
His campaign was not going well.
These animals make very good pets if treated well (= with kindness).
People spoke well of (= spoke with approval of) him.
She took it very well (= did not react too badly), all things considered.
They lived well (= in comfort and spending a lot of money) and were generous with their money.
She was determined to marry well (= marry somebody rich and/or with a high social position).
It's important to value and treat employees well.
The play has been well reviewed.
The performance is well served by excellent designs and lighting.
The product has been well received by consumers.
She is well placed to explain the situation.
Money spent on looking after your health is money very well spent.
Tickets are selling well for the concert.
a well written essay
His work is well represented in the museum.
a well educated young woman
The dress fitted well.
Goodnight! Sleep well!
Students are responding well to the changes.
These plants perform well in stony soil.
She is well dressed.
a well-dressed woman.
better-known poets
the best-dressed person in the room.

meanings.def: completely and properly
examples: Add the lemon juice and mix well.
The surface must be well prepared before you start to paint.
How well do you know Carla?
He's well able to take care of himself.
a well trained dog

meanings.def: to a great extent or degree
examples: He was driving at well over the speed limit.
She is well aware of the dangers.
They are very well suited to each other.
a well-loved tale
The castle is well worth a visit.
He liked her well enough (= to a reasonable degree) but he wasn't going to make a close friend of her.
(British English, informal) I was well annoyed, I can tell you.
The party was planned well in advance.
a well deserved reputation
She knew my family very well.
a well thought-out plan
The process is already well underway.
a well equipped kitchen

meanings.def: easily
examples: She could well afford to pay for it herself.

meanings.def: probably
examples: You may well be right.
It may well be that the train is delayed.

meanings.def: with good reason
examples: I can't very well leave now.
I couldn't very well refuse to help them, could I?
‘What are we doing here?’ ‘You may well ask (= I don't really know either).’

meanings.def: in addition to somebody/something; too
examples: Are they coming as well?
They sell books as well as newspapers.
She is a talented musician as well as being a photographer.
I went to New York last year, and I also spent some time in Washington.
‘I’m going home now.’ ‘I’ll come too.’.
She hasn’t phoned and she hasn’t written either.
You can have a burger, but you can’t have fries as well.

meanings.def: to be getting healthier after an illness; to be in good health after a birth
examples: Mother and baby are doing well.

meanings.def: to have nearly achieved something and be going to achieve it soon
examples: She is well on the way to recovery.
He is well on the way to establishing himself among the top ten players in the world.

meanings.def: to be lucky that you are not involved in something unpleasant or difficult to deal with
examples: I don’t know exactly what’s been going on. I only know that you’re well out of it.

meanings.def: to know a lot about something
examples: He's well up in all the latest developments.

meanings.def: used to emphasize an angry statement or an order
examples: You can bloody well keep your job—I don't want it!
‘I’m not coming.’ ‘Yes, you bloody well are!’
You're fucking well coming whether you want to or not.

meanings.def: used to emphasize an angry statement or an order
examples: You can bloody well keep your job—I don't want it!
‘I’m not coming.’ ‘Yes, you bloody well are!’

meanings.def: to be successful
examples: Jack is doing very well at school.

meanings.def: to treat somebody generously
to become successful or rich
to make a profit or get money from somebody/something
to be sensible or wise to do something
examples: He would do well to concentrate more on his work.
You did well to sell when the price was high.

meanings.def: used to emphasize an angry statement or an order
examples: You're fucking well coming whether you want to or not.

meanings.def: used to emphasize a statement when you are annoyed about something
examples: If you don't come now, you can jolly well walk home!

meanings.def: used to criticize somebody by saying that they should realize or understand something
examples: You know as well as I do that you're being unreasonable.

meanings.def: to be very aware of a fact and unable to deny or ignore it
examples: He knew full well what she thought of it.

meanings.def: to not get involved in something that you have no connection with
examples: When it comes to other people's arguments, it's better to leave well alone.

meanings.def: if you are going to be punished for doing something wrong, whether it is a big or small thing, you may as well do the big thing
used to say that something seems the best thing to do in the situation that you are in, although you may not really want to do it
examples: If no one else wants it, we might as well give it to him.

meanings.def: used to say that there is no real difference between two things that you might do
examples: If you are going to have sugar, you may as well have a bar of chocolate.

meanings.def: to have good intentions, although their effect may not be good
almost; almost completely
examples: One dog looks pretty much like another to me.
He goes out pretty well every night.
The first stage is pretty near finished.

meanings.def: completely
examples: By that time we were well and truly lost.

meanings.def: having made good progress
examples: If we got Terry to do that, we'd be well away.

meanings.def: drunk or in a deep sleep
to be good friends with somebody, especially somebody important
examples: She seems to be well in with all the right people.

idioms.def: in addition to somebody/something; too
examples: Are they coming as well?
They sell books as well as newspapers.
She is a talented musician as well as being a photographer.
I went to New York last year, and I also spent some time in Washington.
‘I’m going home now.’ ‘I’ll come too.’.
She hasn’t phoned and she hasn’t written either.
You can have a burger, but you can’t have fries as well.

idioms.def: to be getting healthier after an illness; to be in good health after a birth
examples: Mother and baby are doing well.

idioms.idiom: be well on the way to something/doing something
idioms.def: to have nearly achieved something and be going to achieve it soon
examples: She is well on the way to recovery.
He is well on the way to establishing himself among the top ten players in the world.

idioms.def: to be lucky that you are not involved in something unpleasant or difficult to deal with
examples: I don’t know exactly what’s been going on. I only know that you’re well out of it.

idioms.def: to know a lot about something
examples: He's well up in all the latest developments.

idioms.def: used to emphasize an angry statement or an order
examples: You can bloody well keep your job—I don't want it!
‘I’m not coming.’ ‘Yes, you bloody well are!’
You're fucking well coming whether you want to or not.

idioms.def: used to emphasize an angry statement or an order
examples: You can bloody well keep your job—I don't want it!
‘I’m not coming.’ ‘Yes, you bloody well are!’

idioms.def: to be successful
examples: Jack is doing very well at school.

idioms.def: to treat somebody generously
to become successful or rich
to make a profit or get money from somebody/something
to be sensible or wise to do something
examples: He would do well to concentrate more on his work.
You did well to sell when the price was high.

idioms.def: used to emphasize an angry statement or an order
examples: You're fucking well coming whether you want to or not.

idioms.def: used to emphasize a statement when you are annoyed about something
examples: If you don't come now, you can jolly well walk home!

idioms.idiom: know something as well as I do
idioms.def: used to criticize somebody by saying that they should realize or understand something
examples: You know as well as I do that you're being unreasonable.

idioms.def: to be very aware of a fact and unable to deny or ignore it
examples: He knew full well what she thought of it.

idioms.def: to not get involved in something that you have no connection with
examples: When it comes to other people's arguments, it's better to leave well alone.

idioms.idiom: (you, etc.) may/might as well be hanged/hung for a sheep as (for) a lamb
idioms.def: if you are going to be punished for doing something wrong, whether it is a big or small thing, you may as well do the big thing
used to say that something seems the best thing to do in the situation that you are in, although you may not really want to do it
examples: If no one else wants it, we might as well give it to him.
If you are going to have sugar, you may as well have a bar of chocolate.

idioms.def: to have good intentions, although their effect may not be good
almost; almost completely
examples: One dog looks pretty much like another to me.
He goes out pretty well every night.
The first stage is pretty near finished.

idioms.def: completely
examples: By that time we were well and truly lost.

idioms.def: having made good progress
examples: If we got Terry to do that, we'd be well away.

idioms.def: to be good friends with somebody, especially somebody important
examples: She seems to be well in with all the right people.

meanings.def: in good health
examples: I don't feel very well.
Is she well enough to travel?
Get well soon! (= for example, on a card)
I'm better now, thank you.
(informal) He's not a well man.
I’m not feeling very well.
Is he well enough to travel?
Are you feeling all right?
She says she’s OK now, and will be back at work tomorrow.
‘How are you?’ ‘Fine, thanks.’
Keep healthy by exercising regularly.
After a few weeks she was feeling stronger.
I go swimming every day in order to keep fit.
I hope you get well soon.
She's quite well at the moment.
You look very well!
‘How are you?’ ‘Very well, thanks.’
I hope you're keeping well.
I'm not feeling very well.
Wait till you're better before you go back to work.
He discovered that his mother was alive and well.
I'm not going until I know he's safe and well.

meanings.def: in a good state or position
examples: It seems that all is not well at home.
All's well that ends well (= used when something has ended happily, even though you thought it might not).

meanings.def: sensible; a good idea
examples: It would be just as well to call and say we might be late.
(formal) It would be well to start early.

meanings.def: still living and not injured or harmed
examples: The missing student was found alive and well in Newcastle.

meanings.def: still popular or successful
examples: Singapore's literary scene is alive and well.
Contrary to popular belief, the tourism industry is alive and well in this part of the world.

meanings.def: used to criticize or reject a remark that somebody has made, especially when they were trying to make you feel happier about something
examples: It's all very well for you to say it doesn't matter, but I've put a lot of work into this and I want it to be a success.

meanings.def: quite good but not exactly what is wanted
examples: That's all well and good, but why didn't he call her to say so?

idioms.def: still living and not injured or harmed
examples: The missing student was found alive and well in Newcastle.
Singapore's literary scene is alive and well.
Contrary to popular belief, the tourism industry is alive and well in this part of the world.

idioms.idiom: all very well (for somebody) (to do something)
idioms.def: used to criticize or reject a remark that somebody has made, especially when they were trying to make you feel happier about something
examples: It's all very well for you to say it doesn't matter, but I've put a lot of work into this and I want it to be a success.

idioms.def: quite good but not exactly what is wanted
examples: That's all well and good, but why didn't he call her to say so?

meanings.def: used to express surprise, anger or relief
examples: Well, well—I would never have guessed it!
Well, really! What a thing to say!
Well, thank goodness that's over!

meanings.def: used to show that you accept that something cannot be changed
examples: Well, it can't be helped.
‘We lost.’ ‘Oh, well. Better luck next time.’

meanings.def: used to agree to something, rather unwillingly
examples: Well, I suppose I could fit you in at 3.45.
Oh, very well, then, if you insist.

meanings.def: used when continuing a conversation after a break
examples: Well, as I was saying…

meanings.def: used to say that something is uncertain
examples: ‘Do you want to come?’ ‘Well, I'm not sure.’

meanings.def: used to show that you are waiting for somebody to say something
examples: Well? Are you going to tell us or not?

meanings.def: used to mark the end of a conversation
examples: Well, I'd better be going now.

meanings.def: used when you are stopping to consider your next words
examples: I think it happened, well, towards the end of last summer.

meanings.def: used when you want to correct or change something that you have just said
examples: There were thousands of people there—well, hundreds, anyway.

meanings.def: used to express surprise
I agree completely
examples: ‘We must stand up for ourselves.’ ‘Well said, John.’

idioms.def: used to express surprise
I agree completely
examples: ‘We must stand up for ourselves.’ ‘Well said, John.’

meanings.def: a deep hole in the ground from which people obtain water. The sides of wells are usually covered with brick or stone and there is usually a cover or a small wall at the top of the well.
examples: to dig/sink a well
The dog fell down a well.

meanings.def: a hole made in the ground to obtain oil
a narrow space in a building that drops down from a high to a low level, giving room for stairs or a lift, or to allow light into the building
examples: Two generous light wells in the main floor bring light down to the basement.

meanings.def: the space in front of the judge in a court, where the lawyers sit
